title: Working with the tsg package
text: generate_frequency() function creates frequency tables one categorical variables data frame. supports variety enhancements, sorting, adding totals percentages, handling missing values, customizing labels. function highly versatile can work grouped data, outputting either single table list tables.

title: Working with the tsg package
code: person_record |>    generate_frequency(sex) #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   category   frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>      <int>   <dbl> #> 1 1 [Male]        1516    52.0 #> 2 2 [Female]      1402    48.0 #> 3 0 [Total]       2918   100

title: Working with the tsg package
text: pass multiple variables, generate frequency tables variable separately list.
code: person_record |>   generate_frequency(sex, age, marital_status) #> $Sex #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   category   frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>      <int>   <dbl> #> 1 1 [Male]        1516    52.0 #> 2 2 [Female]      1402    48.0 #> 3 0 [Total]       2918   100   #>  #> $Age #> # A tibble: 96 × 3 #>    category frequency percent #>    <chr>        <int>   <dbl> #>  1 16              82    2.81 #>  2 15              75    2.57 #>  3 12              74    2.54 #>  4 13              70    2.40 #>  5 20              68    2.33 #>  6 14              66    2.26 #>  7 19              66    2.26 #>  8 11              61    2.09 #>  9 24              61    2.09 #> 10 18              59    2.02 #> # ℹ 86 more rows #>  #> $`Marital status` #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   category                 frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>                    <int>   <dbl> #> 1 1 [Single/never married]      1544   52.9  #> 2 2 [Married]                    769   26.4  #> 3 3 [Common law/live-in]         424   14.5  #> 4 4 [Widowed]                    138    4.73 #> 5 6 [Separated]                   43    1.47 #> 6 0 [Total]                     2918  100    #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "tsg"  "tsgf" "list"

title: Working with the tsg package
text: can also specify grouping using group_by() dplyr calculate frequency table group. default, function generate single frequency table grouped data. want generate list frequency tables group, can set group_as_list = TRUE.
code: person_record |>   dplyr::group_by(sex) |>   generate_frequency(marital_status) #> # A tibble: 12 × 4 #>    sex        category                 frequency percent #>    <int+lbl>  <int+lbl>                    <int>   <dbl> #>  1 1 [Male]   1 [Single/never married]       859   56.7  #>  2 1 [Male]   2 [Married]                    387   25.5  #>  3 1 [Male]   3 [Common law/live-in]         211   13.9  #>  4 1 [Male]   4 [Widowed]                     40    2.64 #>  5 1 [Male]   6 [Separated]                   19    1.25 #>  6 1 [Male]   0 [Total]                     1516  100    #>  7 2 [Female] 1 [Single/never married]       685   48.9  #>  8 2 [Female] 2 [Married]                    382   27.2  #>  9 2 [Female] 3 [Common law/live-in]         213   15.2  #> 10 2 [Female] 4 [Widowed]                     98    6.99 #> 11 2 [Female] 6 [Separated]                   24    1.71 #> 12 2 [Female] 0 [Total]                     1402  100 person_record |>   dplyr::group_by(sex) |>   generate_frequency(marital_status, group_as_list = TRUE) #> $Male #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   sex       category                 frequency percent #>   <int+lbl> <int+lbl>                    <int>   <dbl> #> 1 1 [Male]  1 [Single/never married]       859   56.7  #> 2 1 [Male]  2 [Married]                    387   25.5  #> 3 1 [Male]  3 [Common law/live-in]         211   13.9  #> 4 1 [Male]  4 [Widowed]                     40    2.64 #> 5 1 [Male]  6 [Separated]                   19    1.25 #> 6 1 [Male]  0 [Total]                     1516  100    #>  #> $Female #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   sex        category                 frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>  <int+lbl>                    <int>   <dbl> #> 1 2 [Female] 1 [Single/never married]       685   48.9  #> 2 2 [Female] 2 [Married]                    382   27.2  #> 3 2 [Female] 3 [Common law/live-in]         213   15.2  #> 4 2 [Female] 4 [Widowed]                     98    6.99 #> 5 2 [Female] 6 [Separated]                   24    1.71 #> 6 2 [Female] 0 [Total]                     1402  100    #>  #> attr(,"groups") #> [1] "sex" #> attr(,"group_attrs") #> attr(,"group_attrs")$sex #> attr(,"group_attrs")$sex$labels #>   Male Female  #>      1      2  #>  #> attr(,"group_attrs")$sex$label #> [1] "Sex" #>  #> attr(,"group_attrs")$sex$class #> [1] "haven_labelled" "vctrs_vctr"     "integer"        #>  #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "tsg"  "tsgf" "list"

title: Working with the tsg package
text: default, output sorted frequency descending order. sort_value set FALSE, output sorted variable values ascending order. multiple variables specified, can indicate variable/s /excluded sorting using sort_except argument.
code: person_record |>   generate_frequency(age, sort_value = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 96 × 3 #>    category frequency percent #>    <chr>        <int>   <dbl> #>  1 16              82    2.81 #>  2 15              75    2.57 #>  3 12              74    2.54 #>  4 13              70    2.40 #>  5 20              68    2.33 #>  6 14              66    2.26 #>  7 19              66    2.26 #>  8 11              61    2.09 #>  9 24              61    2.09 #> 10 18              59    2.02 #> # ℹ 86 more rows  person_record |>   generate_frequency(age, sort_value = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 96 × 3 #>    category frequency percent #>    <chr>        <int>   <dbl> #>  1 0               32    1.10 #>  2 1               42    1.44 #>  3 2               44    1.51 #>  4 3               41    1.41 #>  5 4               44    1.51 #>  6 5               54    1.85 #>  7 6               44    1.51 #>  8 7               47    1.61 #>  9 8               56    1.92 #> 10 9               48    1.64 #> # ℹ 86 more rows person_record |>   generate_frequency(     sex,      age,      marital_status,      # vector of variable names (character) to exclude from sorting     sort_except = "age"    ) #> $Sex #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   category   frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>      <int>   <dbl> #> 1 1 [Male]        1516    52.0 #> 2 2 [Female]      1402    48.0 #> 3 0 [Total]       2918   100   #>  #> $Age #> # A tibble: 96 × 3 #>    category frequency percent #>    <chr>        <int>   <dbl> #>  1 0               32    1.10 #>  2 1               42    1.44 #>  3 2               44    1.51 #>  4 3               41    1.41 #>  5 4               44    1.51 #>  6 5               54    1.85 #>  7 6               44    1.51 #>  8 7               47    1.61 #>  9 8               56    1.92 #> 10 9               48    1.64 #> # ℹ 86 more rows #>  #> $`Marital status` #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   category                 frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>                    <int>   <dbl> #> 1 1 [Single/never married]      1544   52.9  #> 2 2 [Married]                    769   26.4  #> 3 3 [Common law/live-in]         424   14.5  #> 4 4 [Widowed]                    138    4.73 #> 5 6 [Separated]                   43    1.47 #> 6 0 [Total]                     2918  100    #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "tsg"  "tsgf" "list"

title: Working with the tsg package
text: can specify top n frequent values display frequency table, sort_value TRUE. default, show top-n values plus remaining values grouped “Others”. want show top-n values exclude rest, set top_n_only = TRUE.
code: person_record |>   generate_frequency(     marital_status,     #top_n = 3   ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   category                 frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>                    <int>   <dbl> #> 1 1 [Single/never married]      1544   52.9  #> 2 2 [Married]                    769   26.4  #> 3 3 [Common law/live-in]         424   14.5  #> 4 4 [Widowed]                    138    4.73 #> 5 6 [Separated]                   43    1.47 #> 6 0 [Total]                     2918  100 person_record |>   generate_frequency(     marital_status,      #top_n = 3,     #top_n_only = TRUE   ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   category                 frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>                    <int>   <dbl> #> 1 1 [Single/never married]      1544   52.9  #> 2 2 [Married]                    769   26.4  #> 3 3 [Common law/live-in]         424   14.5  #> 4 4 [Widowed]                    138    4.73 #> 5 6 [Separated]                   43    1.47 #> 6 0 [Total]                     2918  100

title: Working with the tsg package
text: can also specify whether include exclude NAs (missing values) frequency table.
code: person_record |>   generate_frequency(     employed,     include_na = TRUE # default   ) #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>   category         frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>            <int>   <dbl> #> 1 2 [No]                1186    40.6 #> 2 1 [Yes]                922    31.6 #> 3 9 [Not reported]       810    27.8 #> 4 0 [Total]             2918   100  # Exclude NA values person_record |>   generate_frequency(     employed,     include_na = FALSE   ) #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   category  frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>     <int>   <dbl> #> 1 2 [No]         1186    56.3 #> 2 1 [Yes]         922    43.7 #> 3 0 [Total]      2108   100

title: Working with the tsg package
text: variables passed generate_frequency() structure (.e. number levels categories), can collapse single frequency table setting collapse_list = TRUE. equivalently using collapse_list() helper function.
code: person_record |>   generate_frequency(     seeing,     hearing,     walking,     remembering,     self_caring,     communicating,      collapse_list = TRUE   ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 13 #>   category           frequency_0 frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_3 frequency_4 #>   <chr>                    <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>       <int> #> 1 Seeing, even if w…        2918        2623          82           9           1 #> 2 Hearing, even if …        2918        2666          43           5           1 #> 3 Walking or climbi…        2918        2658          48           7           2 #> 4 Remembering or co…        2918        2680          28           7           0 #> 5 Self-caring (such…        2918        2671          37           5           2 #> 6 Communicating usi…        2918        2683          25           5           2 #> # ℹ 7 more variables: frequency_9 <int>, percent_0 <dbl>, percent_1 <dbl>, #> #   percent_2 <dbl>, percent_3 <dbl>, percent_4 <dbl>, percent_9 <dbl> person_record |>   generate_frequency(     seeing,     hearing,     walking,     remembering,     self_caring,     communicating   ) |>    collapse_list() #> # A tibble: 6 × 13 #>   category           frequency_0 frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_3 frequency_4 #>   <chr>                    <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>       <int> #> 1 Seeing, even if w…        2918        2623          82           9           1 #> 2 Hearing, even if …        2918        2666          43           5           1 #> 3 Walking or climbi…        2918        2658          48           7           2 #> 4 Remembering or co…        2918        2680          28           7           0 #> 5 Self-caring (such…        2918        2671          37           5           2 #> 6 Communicating usi…        2918        2683          25           5           2 #> # ℹ 7 more variables: frequency_9 <int>, percent_0 <dbl>, percent_1 <dbl>, #> #   percent_2 <dbl>, percent_3 <dbl>, percent_4 <dbl>, percent_9 <dbl>

title: Working with the tsg package
text: can also add cumulative frequency percentage frequency table. can also specify whether express value proportion. can also position total row top table. NOTE: labelled data, value row total automatically set lowest numeric value. default label total row “Total”; want set custom label total row, can use label_total argument.
code: person_record |>   generate_frequency(     sex,      add_cumulative = TRUE,      add_cumulative_percent = TRUE    ) #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   category   frequency percent cumulative cumulative_percent #>   <int+lbl>      <int>   <dbl>      <int>              <dbl> #> 1 1 [Male]        1516    52.0       1516               52.0 #> 2 2 [Female]      1402    48.0       2918              100   #> 3 0 [Total]       2918   100           NA               NA person_record |>   generate_frequency(     marital_status,     as_proportion = TRUE   ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   category                 frequency proportion #>   <int+lbl>                    <int>      <dbl> #> 1 1 [Single/never married]      1544     0.529  #> 2 2 [Married]                    769     0.264  #> 3 3 [Common law/live-in]         424     0.145  #> 4 4 [Widowed]                    138     0.0473 #> 5 6 [Separated]                   43     0.0147 #> 6 0 [Total]                     2918     1 person_record |>   generate_frequency(     marital_status,     position_total = "top"   ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   category                 frequency percent #>   <int+lbl>                    <int>   <dbl> #> 1 0 [Total]                     2918  100    #> 2 1 [Single/never married]      1544   52.9  #> 3 2 [Married]                    769   26.4  #> 4 3 [Common law/live-in]         424   14.5  #> 5 4 [Widowed]                    138    4.73 #> 6 6 [Separated]                   43    1.47

title: Working with the tsg package
text: generate_crosstab() function allows create cross-tabulations two variables, useful exploring relationships categorical variables.

title: Working with the tsg package
text: NOTE: pass one variable, fall back generate_frequency() generate frequency table variable specified.
code: person_record |>   generate_crosstab(marital_status, sex) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   category                 total frequency_1 frequency_2 percent_1 percent_2 #>   <int+lbl>                <int>       <int>       <int>     <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 1 [Single/never married]  1544         859         685      55.6      44.4 #> 2 2 [Married]                769         387         382      50.3      49.7 #> 3 3 [Common law/live-in]     424         211         213      49.8      50.2 #> 4 4 [Widowed]                138          40          98      29.0      71.0 #> 5 6 [Separated]               43          19          24      44.2      55.8 #> 6 0 [Total]                 2918        1516        1402      52.0      48.0

title: Working with the tsg package
text: pass mutliple variables, generate cross-tabulations pair variables separately list.
code: person_record |>   generate_crosstab(     sex,     seeing,     hearing,     walking,     remembering,     self_caring,     communicating   ) #> $`Seeing, even if wearing glasses` #> # A tibble: 3 × 12 #>   category   total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_3 frequency_4 frequency_NA #>   <int+lbl>  <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>        <int> #> 1 1 [Male]    1516        1369          40           4           0          103 #> 2 2 [Female]  1402        1254          42           5           1          100 #> 3 0 [Total]   2918        2623          82           9           1          203 #> # ℹ 5 more variables: percent_1 <dbl>, percent_2 <dbl>, percent_3 <dbl>, #> #   percent_4 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> #>  #> $`Hearing, even if using hearing aid` #> # A tibble: 3 × 12 #>   category   total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_3 frequency_4 frequency_NA #>   <int+lbl>  <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>        <int> #> 1 1 [Male]    1516        1386          23           4           0          103 #> 2 2 [Female]  1402        1280          20           1           1          100 #> 3 0 [Total]   2918        2666          43           5           1          203 #> # ℹ 5 more variables: percent_1 <dbl>, percent_2 <dbl>, percent_3 <dbl>, #> #   percent_4 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> #>  #> $`Walking or climbing steps, even if with cane or artificial leg` #> # A tibble: 3 × 12 #>   category   total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_3 frequency_4 frequency_NA #>   <int+lbl>  <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>        <int> #> 1 1 [Male]    1516        1381          27           4           1          103 #> 2 2 [Female]  1402        1277          21           3           1          100 #> 3 0 [Total]   2918        2658          48           7           2          203 #> # ℹ 5 more variables: percent_1 <dbl>, percent_2 <dbl>, percent_3 <dbl>, #> #   percent_4 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> #>  #> $`Remembering or concentrating` #> # A tibble: 3 × 10 #>   category   total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_3 frequency_NA percent_1 #>   <int+lbl>  <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>        <int>     <dbl> #> 1 1 [Male]    1516        1393          17           3          103      91.9 #> 2 2 [Female]  1402        1287          11           4          100      91.8 #> 3 0 [Total]   2918        2680          28           7          203      91.8 #> # ℹ 3 more variables: percent_2 <dbl>, percent_3 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> #>  #> $`Self-caring (such as wasking all over or dressing)` #> # A tibble: 3 × 12 #>   category   total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_3 frequency_4 frequency_NA #>   <int+lbl>  <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>        <int> #> 1 1 [Male]    1516        1391          19           2           1          103 #> 2 2 [Female]  1402        1280          18           3           1          100 #> 3 0 [Total]   2918        2671          37           5           2          203 #> # ℹ 5 more variables: percent_1 <dbl>, percent_2 <dbl>, percent_3 <dbl>, #> #   percent_4 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> #>  #> $`Communicating using his/her casual (customary) language` #> # A tibble: 3 × 12 #>   category   total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_3 frequency_4 frequency_NA #>   <int+lbl>  <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>       <int>        <int> #> 1 1 [Male]    1516        1396          13           3           1          103 #> 2 2 [Female]  1402        1287          12           2           1          100 #> 3 0 [Total]   2918        2683          25           5           2          203 #> # ℹ 5 more variables: percent_1 <dbl>, percent_2 <dbl>, percent_3 <dbl>, #> #   percent_4 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "tsg"  "tsgc" "list"

title: Working with the tsg package
text: can also specify grouping group_by() dplyr calculate cross-tabulation group. want generate list cross-tabulations group, can set group_as_list = TRUE.
code: person_record |>   dplyr::group_by(sex) |>   generate_crosstab(marital_status, employed) #> # A tibble: 12 × 9 #>    sex        category      total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_NA percent_1 #>    <int+lbl>  <int+lbl>     <int>       <int>       <int>        <int>     <dbl> #>  1 1 [Male]   1 [Single/ne…   859         127         330          402     14.8  #>  2 1 [Male]   2 [Married]     387         274         108            5     70.8  #>  3 1 [Male]   3 [Common la…   211         169          41            1     80.1  #>  4 1 [Male]   4 [Widowed]      40          18          21            1     45    #>  5 1 [Male]   6 [Separated]    19          11           8            0     57.9  #>  6 1 [Male]   0 [Total]      1516         599         508          409     39.5  #>  7 2 [Female] 1 [Single/ne…   685          63         234          388      9.20 #>  8 2 [Female] 2 [Married]     382         155         218            9     40.6  #>  9 2 [Female] 3 [Common la…   213          67         142            4     31.5  #> 10 2 [Female] 4 [Widowed]      98          26          72            0     26.5  #> 11 2 [Female] 6 [Separated]    24          12          12            0     50    #> 12 2 [Female] 0 [Total]      1402         323         678          401     23.0  #> # ℹ 2 more variables: percent_2 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> person_record |>   dplyr::group_by(sex) |>   generate_crosstab(marital_status, employed, group_as_list = TRUE) #> $Male #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   sex       category        total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_NA percent_1 #>   <int+lbl> <int+lbl>       <int>       <int>       <int>        <int>     <dbl> #> 1 1 [Male]  1 [Single/neve…   859         127         330          402      14.8 #> 2 1 [Male]  2 [Married]       387         274         108            5      70.8 #> 3 1 [Male]  3 [Common law/…   211         169          41            1      80.1 #> 4 1 [Male]  4 [Widowed]        40          18          21            1      45   #> 5 1 [Male]  6 [Separated]      19          11           8            0      57.9 #> 6 1 [Male]  0 [Total]        1516         599         508          409      39.5 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: percent_2 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> #>  #> $Female #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   sex        category       total frequency_1 frequency_2 frequency_NA percent_1 #>   <int+lbl>  <int+lbl>      <int>       <int>       <int>        <int>     <dbl> #> 1 2 [Female] 1 [Single/nev…   685          63         234          388      9.20 #> 2 2 [Female] 2 [Married]      382         155         218            9     40.6  #> 3 2 [Female] 3 [Common law…   213          67         142            4     31.5  #> 4 2 [Female] 4 [Widowed]       98          26          72            0     26.5  #> 5 2 [Female] 6 [Separated]     24          12          12            0     50    #> 6 2 [Female] 0 [Total]       1402         323         678          401     23.0  #> # ℹ 2 more variables: percent_2 <dbl>, percent_NA <dbl> #>  #> attr(,"groups") #> [1] "sex" #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "tsg"  "tsgc" "list"

what: Percent or proportion by row or column
title: Working with the tsg package
text: can specify whether calculate percentage proportion row column using percent_by_column argument. set TRUE, percentage calculated column; set FALSE, calculated row. default FALSE.
code: person_record |>   generate_crosstab(     marital_status,     sex,     percent_by_column = TRUE   ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   category       frequency_total frequency_1 frequency_2 percent_total percent_1 #>   <int+lbl>                <int>       <int>       <int>         <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 1 [Single/nev…            1544         859         685         52.9      56.7  #> 2 2 [Married]                769         387         382         26.4      25.5  #> 3 3 [Common law…             424         211         213         14.5      13.9  #> 4 4 [Widowed]                138          40          98          4.73      2.64 #> 5 6 [Separated]               43          19          24          1.47      1.25 #> 6 0 [Total]                 2918        1516        1402        100       100    #> # ℹ 1 more variable: percent_2 <dbl>

title: Working with the tsg package
text: Just like generate_frequency(), can also specify whether express value proportion. can also position total row top table.
code: person_record |>   generate_crosstab(     marital_status,     sex,     as_proportion = TRUE   ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   category               total frequency_1 frequency_2 proportion_1 proportion_2 #>   <int+lbl>              <int>       <int>       <int>        <dbl>        <dbl> #> 1 1 [Single/never marri…  1544         859         685        0.556        0.444 #> 2 2 [Married]              769         387         382        0.503        0.497 #> 3 3 [Common law/live-in]   424         211         213        0.498        0.502 #> 4 4 [Widowed]              138          40          98        0.290        0.710 #> 5 6 [Separated]             43          19          24        0.442        0.558 #> 6 0 [Total]               2918        1516        1402        0.520        0.480 person_record |>   generate_crosstab(     marital_status,     sex,     position_total = "top"   ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   category                 total frequency_1 frequency_2 percent_1 percent_2 #>   <int+lbl>                <int>       <int>       <int>     <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 0 [Total]                 2918        1516        1402      52.0      48.0 #> 2 1 [Single/never married]  1544         859         685      55.6      44.4 #> 3 2 [Married]                769         387         382      50.3      49.7 #> 4 3 [Common law/live-in]     424         211         213      49.8      50.2 #> 5 4 [Widowed]                138          40          98      29.0      71.0 #> 6 6 [Separated]               43          19          24      44.2      55.8

title: Working with the tsg package
text: can export frequency table cross-tabulation Excel using write_xlsx().

title: Working with the tsg package
code: person_record |>    generate_frequency(sex) |>    write_xlsx(path = "table-01.xlsx")

title: Working with the tsg package
text: can add title subtitle table using add_table_title() add_table_subtitle() functions. can also add end notes table using add_source_note() add_footnote() functions. Alternatively, can directly add table title, subtitle, source_note, footnotes specifying arguments write_xlsx() function.
code: person_record |>    generate_crosstab(marital_status, sex) |>    add_table_title("Marital Status by Sex") |>   add_table_subtitle("Sample dataset: person_record") |>   write_xlsx(path = "table-02.xlsx") person_record |>    generate_crosstab(marital_status, sex) |>    add_table_title("Marital Status by Sex") |>   add_table_subtitle("Sample dataset: person_record") |>   add_source_note("Source: person_record dataset") |>   add_footnote("This is a footnote for the table") |>   write_xlsx(path = "table-03.xlsx") person_record |>    generate_crosstab(marital_status, sex) |>    write_xlsx(     path = "table-03.xlsx",     table_title = "Marital Status by Sex",     table_subtitle = "Sample dataset: person_record",     source_note = "Source: person_record dataset",     footnotes = "This is a footnote for the table"   )

title: Working with the tsg package
text: can use add_facade() function apply facade table. facade set styling options can applied table customize appearance. want customize appearance table, can use facade argument specify YAML facade file. facade file contains styling options table, font size, border style, background color, text alignment. can generate template facade file using generate_template() function customize needs.
code: person_record |>    generate_frequency(sex) |>    add_facade(     table.offsetRow = 2,      table.offsetCol = 1   ) |>    write_xlsx(     path = "table-04.xlsx",     # Using built-in facade     facade = get_tsg_facade("yolo")   ) person_record |>    generate_frequency(sex) |>    write_xlsx(     path = "table-05.xlsx",     # Using built-in facade     facade = get_tsg_facade("yolo")   )

title: Working with the tsg package
text: generate_output() can used generate save output file specified format (e.g., Excel, HTML, PDF, Word). supports various formats can handle different data structures. NOTE: moment, supports Excel output. formats yet implemented.
code: person_record |>    generate_frequency(sex) |>    generate_output(path = "table-06.xlsx")

title: Add a facade to a tsg table — add_facade
text: data tsg table object facade added. typically data frame tibble processed using tsg functions. table.offsetRow Row offset table table.offsetCol Column offset table table.gridLines Boolean indicating whether show grid lines table table.tabColour Color table tab (Excel worksheet) output file. Can hexadecimal color code (e.g., "#FF0000" red) named color (e.g., "red"). table.fontName, title.fontName, subtitle.fontName, header.fontName, spanner.fontName, body.fontName, row_group.fontName, col_first.fontName, col_last.fontName, source_note.fontName, footnotes.fontName Font name font family table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. table.fontSize, title.fontSize, subtitle.fontSize, header.fontSize, spanner.fontSize, body.fontSize, col_first.fontSize, col_last.fontSize, row_group.fontSize, source_note.fontSize, footnotes.fontSize Font size table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. table.fontColour, title.fontColour, subtitle.fontColour, header.fontColour, spanner.fontColour, body.fontColour, col_first.fontColour, col_last.fontColour, row_group.fontColour, source_note.fontColour, footnotes.fontColour Font color table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. Can hexadecimal color code (e.g., "#FF0000" red) named color (e.g., "red"). table.bgFill, title.bgFill, subtitle.bgFill, header.bgFill, spanner.bgFill, body.bgFill, col_first.bgFill, col_last.bgFill, row_group.bgFill, source_note.bgFill, footnotes.bgFill Background fill color table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. Can hexadecimal color code (e.g., "#FF0000" red) named color (e.g., "red"). table.fgFill, title.fgFill, subtitle.fgFill, header.fgFill, spanner.fgFill, body.fgFill, col_first.fgFill, col_last.fgFill, row_group.fgFill, source_note.fgFill, footnotes.fgFill Foreground fill color table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. Can hexadecimal color code (e.g., "#FF0000" red) named color (e.g., "red"). table.halign, title.halign, subtitle.halign, header.halign, spanner.halign, body.halign, col_first.halign, col_last.halign, row_group.halign, source_note.halign, footnotes.halign Horizontal alignment table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. Can "left", "center", "right". table.valign, title.valign, subtitle.valign, header.valign, spanner.valign, body.valign, col_first.valign, col_last.valign, row_group.valign, source_note.valign, footnotes.valign Vertical alignment table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. Can "top", "middle", "bottom". table.wrapText, title.wrapText, subtitle.wrapText, header.wrapText, spanner.wrapText, body.wrapText, col_first.wrapText, col_last.wrapText, row_group.wrapText, source_note.wrapText, footnotes.wrapText Logical indicating whether wrap text table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. table.indent, title.indent, subtitle.indent, header.indent, spanner.indent, body.indent, col_first.indent, col_last.indent, row_group.indent, source_note.indent, footnotes.indent Indentation table, title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. Can numeric value indicating number spaces indent. Defaults NULL. table.locked Logical indicating whether table locked. table.hidden Logical indicating whether table (Excel worksheet) hidden. table.decimalPrecision Numeric value indicating number decimal places display numeric columns. table.decimalCols Character vector column names decimal formatting applied. table.lastRowBold Logical indicating whether last row table bold. table.width, col_first.width, col_last.width, row_group.width Column widths table, first column, last column, row group header respectively. Can numeric value indicating width points. table.widthOffset Numeric value indicating width offset table. title.border, subtitle.border, header.border, spanner.border, body.border, col_first.border, col_last.border, row_group.border, source_note.border, footnotes.border, border_header.border Border style title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. Can string representing border style. border_header.border used header border style. title.borderColour, subtitle.borderColour, header.borderColour, spanner.borderColour, body.borderColour, col_first.borderColour, col_last.borderColour, row_group.borderColour, source_note.borderColour, footnotes.borderColour, border_header.borderColour, border_outer.borderColour Border color title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. Can hexadecimal color code (e.g., "#FF0000" red) named color (e.g., "red"). border_header.borderColour border_outer.borderColour used header outer borders table. title.borderStyle, subtitle.borderStyle, header.borderStyle, spanner.borderStyle, body.borderStyle, col_first.borderStyle, col_last.borderStyle, row_group.borderStyle, source_note.borderStyle, footnotes.borderStyle, border_header.borderStyle Border style title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. border_header.borderStyle used header border style. title.textDecoration, subtitle.textDecoration, header.textDecoration, spanner.textDecoration, body.textDecoration, col_first.textDecoration, col_last.textDecoration, row_group.textDecoration, source_note.textDecoration, footnotes.textDecoration Text decoration title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, first column, last column, row group header, source note, footnotes respectively. title.height, subtitle.height, header.height, spanner.height, body.height, source_note.height, footnotes.height, border_bottom.height Height title, subtitle, header, spanner, body, source note, footnotes, bottom border table respectively. Can numeric value indicating height points. body.numFmt, col_first.numFmt, col_last.numFmt Numeric format body, first column, last column respectively. Can string representing numeric format.

title: Generate cross-tabulation — generate_crosstab
text: Generate cross-tabulation

title: Generate cross-tabulation — generate_crosstab
code: generate_crosstab(   data,   x,   ...,   add_total = TRUE,   add_total_row = TRUE,   add_total_column = TRUE,   add_percent = TRUE,   as_proportion = FALSE,   percent_by_column = FALSE,   name_separator = "_",   label_separator = "__",   label_total = "Total",   label_total_column = NULL,   label_total_row = NULL,   label_na = "Not reported",   include_na = TRUE,   recode_na = "auto",   label_as_group_name = TRUE,   group_separator = " - ",   group_as_list = FALSE,   calculate_per_group = TRUE,   expand_categories = TRUE,   position_total = "bottom",   sort_column_names = TRUE,   convert_factor = FALSE,   metadata = NULL )

title: Generate cross-tabulation — generate_crosstab
text: data data frame (typically tibble) containing variables summarize. x variable use rows cross-tabulation. ... Additional variable(s) use columns cross-tabulation. none provided, frequency table x returned. add_total Logical. TRUE, adds total row /column. add_total_row Logical. TRUE, adds total row. add_total_column Logical. TRUE, adds total column. add_percent Logical. TRUE, adds percent proportion values table. as_proportion Logical. TRUE, displays proportions instead percentages (range 0–1). percent_by_column Logical. TRUE, percentages calculated column; otherwise, row. name_separator Character. Separator used constructing variable names output. label_separator Character. Separator used constructing labels output. label_total Character. Label used total row/category. label_total_column Character. Label used total column/category. label_total_row Character. Label used total row/category. label_na Character. Label use missing (NA) values. include_na Logical. TRUE, includes missing values cross table. recode_na Character NULL. Value used replace missing values labelled vectors; "auto" determine code automatically. label_as_group_name Logical. TRUE, uses variable label grouping variable(s) name output list. group_separator Character. Separator used constructing group names output list. group_as_list Logical. TRUE, output list data frames, one combination grouping variable(s). calculate_per_group Logical. TRUE, calculates cross-tabulation separately group defined grouping variable(s). expand_categories Logical. TRUE, ensures categories x represented output, even zero counts. position_total Character. Position total row/column; either "bottom" "top" rows, "right" "left" columns. sort_column_names Logical. TRUE, sorts column names output. convert_factor Logical. TRUE, converts labelled variables factors output. See also convert_factor(). metadata named list optional metadata attach attributes, e.g. title, subtitle, source_note.

title: Generate cross-tabulation — generate_crosstab
text: data frame list data frames containing cross-tabulation results. group_as_list TRUE, output list data frames, one combination grouping variable(s). Otherwise, single data frame returned. data frame includes counts , specified, percentages proportions combination x additional variables provided ....

title: Generate frequency table — generate_frequency
text: Creates frequency tables one categorical variables, optionally grouped variables. function supports various enhancements sorting, totals, percentages, cumulative statistics, handling missing values, label customization. returns single table list frequency tables.

title: Generate frequency table — generate_frequency
code: generate_frequency(   data,   ...,   sort_value = TRUE,   sort_desc = TRUE,   sort_except = NULL,   add_total = TRUE,   add_percent = TRUE,   add_cumulative = FALSE,   add_cumulative_percent = FALSE,   as_proportion = FALSE,   include_na = TRUE,   recode_na = "auto",   position_total = c("bottom", "top"),   calculate_per_group = TRUE,   group_separator = " - ",   group_as_list = FALSE,   label_as_group_name = TRUE,   label_stub = NULL,   label_na = "Not reported",   label_total = "Total",   expand_categories = TRUE,   convert_factor = FALSE,   collapse_list = FALSE,   top_n = NULL,   top_n_only = FALSE,   metadata = NULL )

title: Generate frequency table — generate_frequency
text: data data frame (typically tibble) containing variables summarize. ... One unquoted variable names (passed via tidy evaluation) compute frequency tables. sort_value Logical. TRUE, frequency values sorted. sort_desc Logical. TRUE, sorts descending order frequency. sort_value = FALSE, category sorted ascending order. sort_except Optional character vector. Variables exclude sorting. add_total Logical. TRUE, adds total row value frequency table. add_percent Logical. TRUE, adds percent proportion values table. add_cumulative Logical. TRUE, adds cumulative frequency counts. add_cumulative_percent Logical. TRUE, adds cumulative percentages (proportions as_proportion = TRUE). as_proportion Logical. TRUE, displays proportions instead percentages (range 0–1). include_na Logical. TRUE, includes missing values frequency table. recode_na Character NULL. Value used replace missing values labelled vectors; "auto" determine code automatically. position_total Character. place total row: "top" "bottom". calculate_per_group Logical. TRUE, calculates frequencies within groups defined data (group_by() existing grouping). group_separator Character. Separator used concatenating group values list output (group_as_list = TRUE). group_as_list Logical. TRUE, output list frequency tables group combination. label_as_group_name Logical. TRUE, uses variable labels names output list; otherwise, uses variable names. label_stub Optional character vector used labeling output tables (e.g., export display). label_na Character. Label use missing (NA) values. label_total Character. Label used total row/category. expand_categories Logical. TRUE, ensures categories (including zero counts) included output. convert_factor Logical. TRUE, converts labelled variables factors output. See also convert_factor(). collapse_list Logical. TRUE group_as_list = TRUE, collapses list frequency tables single data frame group identifiers. See also collapse_list(). top_n Integer NULL. specified, limits output top n categories frequency. top_n_only Logical. TRUE top_n specified, top n categories included, excluding others. metadata named list optional metadata attach attributes, e.g. title, subtitle, source_note.

title: Generate frequency table — generate_frequency
text: frequency table (tibble, possibly nested) list tables. Additional attributes labels, metadata, grouping information may attached. returned object class "tsg".

what: Generate output in specified format (e.g., xlsx, html, pdf, word) — generate_output
title: Generate output in specified format (e.g., xlsx, html, pdf, word) — generate_output
text: Generate output specified format (e.g., xlsx, html, pdf, word)

title: Generate output in specified format (e.g., xlsx, html, pdf, word) — generate_output
code: generate_output(data, path, ..., format = c("xlsx", "html", "pdf", "word"))

title: Generate output in specified format (e.g., xlsx, html, pdf, word) — generate_output
text: data Preferably tsg class object best results. data frame, tibble, list also supported. path File path save output. ... Additional arguments passed specific format functions. format Output format. One "xlsx", "html", "pdf", "word".

title: Generate output in specified format (e.g., xlsx, html, pdf, word) — generate_output
text: Generates saves output file specified format given path.

title: Generate output in specified format (e.g., xlsx, html, pdf, word) — generate_output
code: #' # Generate an xlsx file from a tsg object data <- generate_frequency(dplyr::starwars, sex)  dir_to <- tempdir() generate_output(   data,   file.path(dir_to, "starwars_frequency.xlsx"),   format = "xlsx" )  unlink(file.path(dir_to, "starwars_frequency.xlsx"))

title: Generate a template — generate_template
text: Generate template

title: Generate a template — generate_template
code: generate_template(path, template = c("facade", "table-list"))

title: Generate a template — generate_template
text: path character string specifying path template saved. directory provided, template saved default name based template type. template character string specifying type template generate. Options "facade" YAML facade template "table-list" Excel table list template.

title: Generate a template — generate_template
text: Void. file path template saved.

title: Generate a template — generate_template
code: template_path_facade <- tempfile(fileext = ".yaml") generate_template(template_path_facade, template = "facade")  template_path_table_list <- tempfile(fileext = ".xlsx") generate_template(template_path_table_list, template = "table-list")  unlink(template_path_facade) unlink(template_path_table_list)

what: Write Data to Excel with Titles, Notes, and Styling — write_xlsx
title: Write Data to Excel with Titles, Notes, and Styling — write_xlsx
text: Exports data frame list data frames one multiple Excel files, support titles, subtitles, source notes, footnotes, grouping, custom styles. leverages openxlsx package create styled Excel reports suitable presentation.

title: Write Data to Excel with Titles, Notes, and Styling — write_xlsx
code: write_xlsx(   data,   path,   ...,   sheet_name = NULL,   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   source_note = NULL,   footnotes = NULL,   separate_files = FALSE,   collapse_list = FALSE,   row_group_as_column = FALSE,   names_separator = "__",   include_table_list = FALSE,   table_list_reference = NULL,   facade = get_tsg_facade() )

title: Write Data to Excel with Titles, Notes, and Styling — write_xlsx
text: data data.frame, tibble, named list . list provided: separate_files = FALSE, element written separate sheet one Excel file. separate_files = TRUE, element written Excel file. path file path (separate_files = FALSE) directory path (separate_files = TRUE) Excel file(s) saved. File extension .xlsx automatically added missing. ... Additional arguments passed openxlsx::createWorkbook() openxlsx::addWorksheet(). sheet_name Optional name Excel sheet. Ignored data list separate_files = FALSE. title Optional title displayed data sheet file. subtitle Optional subtitle displayed title. source_note Optional source note displayed data. footnotes Optional character vector footnotes display source note. separate_files Logical. TRUE, list item data saved separate Excel file. collapse_list Logical. TRUE, list data frames merged one sheet (applicable). row_group_as_column Logical. TRUE, row groupings included columns instead grouped titles. names_separator Character used separate column names dealing nested grouped headers. include_table_list Logical. TRUE, table list reference included Excel file. table_list_reference data frame containing table list reference. NULL, generated data. facade list styling options (colors, fonts, sizes, border styles, etc.). Defaults global option tsg.options.facade.

title: Write Data to Excel with Titles, Notes, and Styling — write_xlsx
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side-effect writing Excel file(s).

title: Write Data to Excel with Titles, Notes, and Styling — write_xlsx
text: function supports advanced Excel formatting including: Grouped headers Dynamic column widths Styled titles, subtitles, source notes, footnotes Border styling (inner, outer, header) function designed handle export needs professional reporting contexts.

title: Write Data to Excel with Titles, Notes, and Styling — write_xlsx
